alternateIdentifier.system: University of Wyoming, Department of Zoology and Physiology

dataset.title: Author ZIP codes and topics of study for all research articles of nine leading ecological journals in 2008

creator.organizationName: University of Wyoming, Department of Zoology and Physiology
University of Wyoming, Department of Zoology and Physiology

abstract.para: This data includes the ZIP codes of all Authors of all research publications appearing in the journals Trends in Ecology and Evolution, Annual Review of Ecology, Evolution and Systematics, Ecology Letters, Ecological Monographs, Ecology, Frontiers in Ecology and the Environment, The American Naturalist, Ecological Applications, and Oecologia in the year 2008. The data also includes the volume, issue, and starting page number for all articles, and a score indicating whether or not the article could be classified into any one of 21 topical categories. This data was compiled to map an index of the spatial distribution of ecologistsâ€™ publications throughout the United States.

intellectualRights.para: Obtain permission from data set owner(s)

contact.organizationName: University of Wyoming, Department of Zoology and Physiology

section.title: Survey of journal articles
section.para: Using ISIâ€™s Journal Citation Reports (http://isiwebofknowledge.com/), we selected 40 journals from the subject category â€œecologyâ€ that had the highest ISI 5-year impact factor indices (2004-2008). We targeted general ecological journals, thus we narrowed the group to nine journals (Trends in Ecology and Evolution, Annual Review of Ecology, Evolution and Systematics, Ecology Letters, Ecological Monographs, Ecology, Frontiers in Ecology and the Environment, The American Naturalist, Ecological Applications, and Oecologia) that were representative of the entire discipline of ecology, and that had â‰¥30% of US-based authors in the first issue of 2008. We then recorded author addresses for all publications in 2008 for each journal. We scored only research articles, and excluded book reviews, editorials, letters to the editor, and news pieces. We scanned titles, abstracts, and the research articles to identify the taxa and habitats studied, as well as the level of ecological organization (organism, population, community, ecosystem) of the primary research questions. Levels within each of these categories were not mutually exclusive.
